bestBHT.bht: Amplias, a fellow laborer in the work of Christ, was beloved in the bonds of Christian fellowship. This contraction of Ampliatus, which occurs in the best texts, is associated with the imperial household. The apostle Paul had a deep affection for Amplias, not because of external factors, but for the Lord's sake and their spiritual relationship as brothers in Christ. This affection was also a result of Amplias' gifts and usefulness in spreading the Gospel of Christ Jesus.

Henry Alford: Beloved in the Lord, i.e. beloved in the bonds of Christian fellowship.
Fellow labourer in (the work of) Christ.
Origen and others have confounded Apelles with the well-known Apollos, but apparently without reason.
Marvin Vincent: Amplias. A contraction of Ampliatus, which is the reading of the best texts.
Philip Schaff: Ampliatus; so the weightier authorities; ‘Amplias’ is an abbreviated form."
A common name in itself, it occurs several times in connection with the imperial household (Lightfoot).
My beloved in the Lord; in Christian fellowship.
Archibald T. Robertson: Ampliatus (Αμπλιατον). Some MSS. have a contracted form Amplias.
John Gill: the apostle had a singular affection for him; and that not upon any external account, as natural relation, riches, honour, learning, c. but for the Lord's sake, and as he was in Christ"
a member of him, and so in a spiritual relation to the apostle a 'brother' of his
because he was honoured with the gifts and graces of the Spirit, and for his usefulness in the Gospel of Christ Jesus

bhtAttempts.bht: Amplias, also known as Ampliatus, is mentioned in the Bible as a beloved fellow laborer in Christ. This name, which is a contracted form, is associated with the imperial household and is a common one. The apostle Paul had a deep affection for Amplias, not because of external factors like wealth or status, but because of their shared bond in the Lord. Amplias was not just a fellow believer, but also a spiritual brother to Paul, a member of the body of Christ. This affection was based on Amplias' gifts and usefulness in spreading the Gospel of Christ Jesus.

Amplias, a beloved fellow laborer in Christ, was cherished by the apostle Paul not for external reasons, but for their shared bond in the Lord. Amplias, a contracted form of Ampliatus, was associated with the imperial household, and their name was a common one. Paul's affection towards Amplias was rooted in their spiritual relationship as brothers in Christ. This affection was also a result of Amplias' gifts and usefulness in spreading the Gospel of Christ Jesus.

This affection was also due to Amplias' gifts and usefulness in the Gospel of Christ Jesus.
